title: SWINNO
text:
The SWINNO project does research at the forefront of innovation and innovation systems. We developed and maintain a unique database of Swedish innovation from 1889 to today. Currently we focus on the impact of innovations as well as social, environmental and economic sustainability.






Funded by












Located at







About us
Our aims
Our team
Partners and funders
Contact us


Contribute
Call for contributions

title: About
text:
A database of Swedish Innovations, 1970 to the present
The SWINNO project is an ongoing series of research projects into Swedish innovations and the Swedish innovation system. Many of these projects are based on the SWINNO database of Swedish innovations, often with additional data from for example surveys, interviews and policy documents. The project is currently headed by Josef Taalbi, and funded by VINNOVA, with additional funding from LUSEM. SWINNO 3. Significant New Products and Processes in Sweden 1970 to the present
In 2020, the SWINNO project has gone into its third phase (SWINNO 3). This phase focuses on the themes of the impact of innovations and social, environmental and economic sustainability. Basic questions and topics are the long-run trends of innovation across different fields; assessing the drivers and obstacles of innovation, e.g., in environmental transitions; network analysis of collaboration patterns and industry ties; and the role of public funding and STI policies.
Beside the research projects, SWINNO 3 continues and expands the data collection of the previous phases. From 2010 onwards, the database has grown from a single spreadsheet into a full-blown relational database that has been developed according to the needs of the SWINNO project and its research. The initial dataset comprised the years 1970 - 2007. SWINNO 2 extended this to 2019 and SWINNO 3 will continue to update for the duration of the project. A historical extension is available for 1908-1969 and is currently extended further back to the late 19th century.
The richness of the SWINNO data allows it to be linked to for example particular regions, the innovating companies (from Sweden’s statistical office) and patents. Patent data is being added to the innovations from 1970 to 2015.
SWINNO data and meta data is publicly available (as far as privacy and copyright allows) as a spreadsheet that can be downloaded here.
The SWINNO project has resulted in a number of papers in high impact academic journals, two PhD theses, a number of student papers, working papers and policy documents.
If you are working with the SWINNO database, please cite the documentation paper:
Sjöö, K., Taalbi, J., Kander, A., & Ljungberg, J. (2014). A Database of Swedish Innovations, 1970-2007. Lund Papers in Economic History, 2014:133.

title: Anders Hylmö
text:
I have a backgorund (Phd) as sociologist of science, with current research interests spanning science and technology studies, valuation studies, research and innovation policy and socio-technical transitions to sustainability.
In Swinno, I have been responsible for interviewing research managers of large Swedish engineering firms and journal editors and journalists, with the purpose of triangulating methodological insights into the validity of the LBIO method.

title: Jakob Nyqvist
text:
I work as a Research Assistant in the SWINNO project.
My responsibilities include collecting innovation data and linking patent data to innovations in the SWINNO database.

title: Astrid Kander
text:
My main research is in the field of environmental economic history. It is about the interrelations of economic growth, innovations, energy and CO2 emissions. The geographical scope is Sweden, Europe and the entire Globe and the time period is from 1800 up until the present. Trade and embodied emissions have been part of my research output in recent years. I also have a project on carbon border adjustment mechanism in EU.
A second strand of research is innovation, more broadly. We have established a consistent Literature Based innovation output database for Sweden and Finland 1970-2013. It will be used to assess policy impacts, collaboration, economic significance of innovations and the interrelations between research and development (R&D), growth and innovation

title: Johanna Fink
text: My research analyzes how government funding and innovation policy affect innovations in Sweden. The main focus is placed on the question whether public innovation activity is line with the country’s environmental targets.

title: Markus Isaksson
text:
I joined the SWINNO project in 2021 as a Research Assistant.
I work with finding and entering innovation data into SWINNO’s database.

title: Contribute
text: You can find useful tools for working with our data at our github.

title: Frank van der Most
text:
I make databases for sustainability research through my company called Rubber Boots Data.
I am developing SWINNO’s database for historical data on Swedish innovations.

title: Josef Taalbi
text:
I am PI of the SWINNO project. My main research interest lies in the study of why, how and when people innovate, and what can be learnt about societal and sustainable transitions from observing patterns in technological change in a long run perspectives.
The SWINNO database enables various entry points to such analyses, spanning both micro and macro analysis, both statistical and in-depth qualitative analysis. I am especially interested in how complementarities and obstacles emerge in technology shifts, shaping long run outcomes, which is possible to study within the SWINNO database using various innovation networks.

title: Valentina Bucaioni
text:
I am a Ph.D. student in Innovation Management at the University of Siena, where I research collaboration networks between universities and companies in science and technology in high-tech industries.
I use the SWINNO data to analyze networks of innovations through patents and products in the Swedish ICT sector.

title: Mathias Johansson
text:
I create systems, datapipelines and visualisations to help researchers leverage everything from simple webscraping and databases to so called Artificial Intelligence models.
In the SWINNO project I am responsible for developing a new export format and a public dashboard.

title: Philipp Jonas Kreutzer
text:
I research the transition to a bioeconomy in the Swedish forest sector.
I use SWINNO to understand the innovation system structure and how innovation shapes sustainability transitions.

title: Sara Torregrosa-Hetland
text:
I am an economic historian with a PhD from the University of Barcelona and worked as a postdoc and researcher at Lund University. I am currently based at the Public University of Navarre, Spain.
My main area of interest is the history of taxation, inequality, and public policies. In the SWINNO project, I analyse innovation policies and their compared impact in Sweden and Finland

title: Our partners and funders
text:
Vinnova is Sweden’s innovation agency. Our mission is to strengthen Sweden’s innovative capacity and contribute to sustainable growth. We work to ensure that Sweden is an innovative force in a sustainable world.





LUSEM is one of the worlds leading economics and management schools. Located at the Lund University, Sweden.
